tossups.question: 1. Description acceptable. The sudden execution of this action over the October 6, 1979 weekend was called the Saturday Night Special. During the “stop-go” policy era, this kind of action characterized the “stop” phase and its opposite the “go” phase. During the Great Moderation, this specific action was undertaken when actual output exceeded potential output, thereby following the Taylor Rule. Though not related to foreign policy, this strategy has historically been supported by so-called “hawks” in response to fears of (*) bubbles. Since December 2015, this action has been taken six times to move away from the zero lower bound, a strategy Jerome Powell is continuing. The 1981 to 1982 recession resulted from Paul Volcker performing this action, which caused a change of around 1000 basis points that was applauded by advocates of “Whip Inflation Now!” For 10 points, identify this action taken by the Federal Reserve to increase the cost of borrowing money.
tossups.answer: the Federal Reserve Board of Governors raising interest rates [accept obvious equivalents like rate hikes in place of “raising the interest rate”; accept the Federal Open Market Committee or the FOMC in place of “Fed”; prompt on partial answers; accept the federal funds rate or the discount rate in place of “interest rate”; prompt on decreasing the money supply or decreasing M0 or decreasing M1 or decreasing M2 or contractionary monetary policy or tightening monetary policy and obvious equivalents; prompt on answers like combating inflation before “inflation” is mentioned; prompt on open market operations] <AA, US History>

tossups.question: 2. Semiotics was applied to the deconstruction of this profession by J. B. Harley, who wrote several volumes on its history. In the 18th century, a standard in this profession named for Rigobert Bonne replaced one named for Johannes Werner. The Pizigano brothers worked in this profession. Charles Hapgood cited Piri Reis’s work in this profession to promote conspiracy theories. The so-called “Majorcan” school of this profession, mostly made of Catalonian Jews, included (*) Abraham Cresques. Medieval members of this profession made heavy use of a so-called “T-O” pattern and created numerous portolans. A man of this profession honored Amerigo Vespucci by using the term “ America” on his Universalis Cosmographia. For 10 points, name this profession of Martin Waldseemuller and Gerardus Mercator.
tossups.answer: cartography [or cartographer; accept any answer that indicates the making of maps; prompt on geography or geographer] <WA, Continental History>

tossups.question: 3. In one essay, this author attacks the writings of Jules Michelet and calls his History of France riddled with “perilous openings for assault.” That essay begins with the line “What is to be thought of her?” referencing a girl from Lorraine who rose to the “perilous station at the right hand of kings.” Another essay by this author includes sections titled “The Vision of Sudden Death” and “Dream-Fugue,” and was published in Blackwood’s Magazine, as was his earlier essay (*) “Suspiria de Profundis.” This author of an essay on “Joan of Arc” recounts meeting Ann, a 16-year-old prostitute, on the corner of Oxford Street in another work. In that work, this author described the time when he gave a package load of a certain substance to a traveling Malay and how he began using that title substance to help him deal with his chronic stomach pains. For 10 points, name this author of Confessions of an English Opium Eater.
tossups.answer: Thomas De Quincey <SB, Essays/Crit>

tossups.question: 4. An inscription records that a king of this empire threw the biggest rager of all time, with 10,000 measures of beer and 10,000 containers of wine serving 47,074 invitees. The Black Obelisk from this empire is a contemporary source on Jehu’s reign. Accounts of invasions by this empire written by king Taharqa record that its armies had their bowstrings eaten by field mice. This empire’s first recorded king heavily propagandized his smashing of the (*) Kassites and conquered the vassal rulers of the rump of the Mitanni kingdom; that ruler was Adad-Nirari I. The “Taylor,” “Oriental Institute,” and “Jerusalem” Prisms contain the propagandistic “Annals” of a king of this empire, which insist that Hezekiah was made a tributary subject and never dealt this empire a defeat. For 10 points, name this empire led by Sennacherib and Ashurbanipal.
tossups.answer: Assyrian Empire [or Ashur] <WA, Historical Sources>

tossups.question: 5. The alternate ending for one novella by this man changes a self-inflicted gunshot to one aimed at the protagonist’s mistress. After dancing with that mistress at a village festival in that novella, Eugene calls her the title word, accusing her of “possessing” him against his will. In another of this author’s novellas, a character elbows his wife in the face, strangles, and stabs her before entering his study to commit suicide, but instead ends up falling asleep for two hours. This author wrote of the peasant girl (*) Stepanida’s allure in The Devil and created the violinist Troukhatchevsky who hides under a piano while trying to escape the insanely jealous Pozdnyshev. In another novella by this author, Gerasim tends to the title character, who suffers a terminal illness after falling while trying to hang curtains. For 10 points name this author of the Kreutzer Sonata and the Death of Ivan Ilyich.
tossups.answer: Leo Tolstoy [or Lev Nikolayevich Tolstoy] <SB, Short Fiction>

tossups.question: 6. A different author’s poem “Racing Stars” describes [emphasize] this author composing a poem in which the speaker’s chest is ripped open by a snake, who deposits a “blazing shard of coal” before being called to “burn Man’s heart” with God’s word. This author of “The Prophet” died “with lead in breast and vengeful fire” due to “gossip” according to a poem that opens “The Bard is dead!” That poem about this author is titled (*) “The Death of the Poet.” A narrative poem by this author contrasts the “eternal sleep” of the nature-conquering Peter with a river that “hurls itself” on the city that Peter built. In that poem, a man witnesses the demise of his beloved Parasha in the flood of the Neva before being chased by the title statue. For 10 points, name this author of “The Bronze Horseman.”
tossups.answer: Alexander Pushkin (“Racing Stars” is by Vladimir Nabokov.) <WA, Poetry>

tossups.question: 7. Juan Ramón Jiménez may have coined the term “naked poetry” after translating Poem 7 from one collection by this author, which describes removing adornments from song. Many of this author’s works were published in Prabasi magazine, where he himself published the works of Lalon. This author wrote that “the time has come when badges of honor make our shame glaring” in a letter to Lord Chelmsford, in which he rejected a previous knighthood after a 1919 (*) massacre in his country. He wrote of a place "where the mind is without fear and the head is held high" and asked that "into that heaven of freedom, Father, let my country awake." W. B. Yeats wrote that he would close man's manuscripts on the bus, “lest some stranger would see how much it moved” him, in the introduction to a poetry collection by this author. For 10 points, name this “Bard of Bengal,” the author of Gitanjali.
tossups.answer: Rabindranath Tagore [or Ravīndranātha Ṭhākura] <SB, Authors/Bios>

tossups.question: 8. Description acceptable. People who took part in this process are the subject of a landmark study by St. Clair Drake and Horace Cayton, whose work was funded by the Works Progress Administration. Isabel Wilkerson interviewed over 1,200 people to write a history of this historical process titled The Warmth of Other Suns. A 2015 exhibit united 60 different works of art depicting this process split between the Phillips Gallery and MoMA. This process is responsible for creating such areas as (*) Bronzeville and Hunters Point, the latter of which coalesced around a World War II shipyard in San Francisco. Participants in this broader process include “King” Oliver’s jazz band, which found work in Chicago. For 10 points, name this major demographic shift in the early 20th century depicted on a series of murals by Jacob Lawrence, which involved much of the South’s population going north.
tossups.answer: The Great Migration [accept answers that indicate a migration of African-Americans out of the South in the early 20th century; prompt on migration or Migration Series] (Drake and Cayton’s book is titled Black Metropolis.) <WA, Historiography>

tossups.question: 9. In No Longer at Ease, a taxi driver goes out of his way to run over one of these animals since, unlike a duck, running over this animal will bring good luck for a new car. One of these animals keeps the newborn child of Bjartur warm after his wife dies during childbirth in Halldor Laxness’ Independent People. The sudden explosive death of one of these animals upsets the security guard Tamaru and may have caused Tsubasa to leave the dowager's house in 1Q84. “He had been alive. He was now dead” are some of the last lines in a (*) biography of one of these animals written by Virginia Woolf. In another novel, the autistic Christopher learns about his mother’s affair with Mr. Shears while investigating the death of one of these animals that had been speared by a garden fork. For 10 points, name this animal whose “curious incident” is explored in the “night-time” in a book by Mark Haddon.
tossups.answer: dogs [anti-prompt on specific types of dogs] <SB, LongFic>

tossups.question: 10. A group of Somalis attempting to migrate to this country began a hunger strike after being held in Villawood. A series of riots by people attempting to enter this country began after Joshua Kaluvia and Louie Efi murdered the 23-year-old Reza Berati. The method for handling immigrants to this nation was drastically changed after an incident in which the Norwegian ship MV Tampa was turned away. Ashmore Island and Cartier Island were excised from this country’s namesake (*) “Migration Zone.” The PNG solution was one attempt to stem asylum seekers to this nation, which previously held them in detention centers on Nauru and Manus Island. For 10 points, name this Anglophone country which regularly receives asylum seekers or “boat people” from Indonesia and Southeast Asia.
tossups.answer: (Commonwealth of) Australia <EM, British/Other History>

tossups.question: 11. Contemporary writers noted that this man frequently appealed to people by baring his thigh and slapping it in public, as well as using the innovative tactic of gesturing and walking around while speaking. This man filed a lawsuit over a satirical depiction of him in the play The Babylonians. This man is condemned to work at the city gates after his downfall in a play in which youth is restored to the old man Demos. In that play, the Paphlagonian oracle is stolen by (*) two slaves who depict this man’s political contemporaries Nicias and Demosthenes. This man is replaced in office by the sausage-seller Agoracitus in a play that was intended to attack his motivations for taking a populist, pro-war position on the Peloponnesian War. For 10 points, name this Athenian politician brutally satirized by Aristophanes in The Knights.
tossups.answer: Cleon <WA, HistInLit>

tossups.question: 12. Select persecution of Sufis in this empire benefited Khalid Shahrazuri, whose Naqshbandi followers were allowed to take over many lodges. A preacher in this empire organized disgruntled peasant mercenaries called sekban into a series of tax revolts. In the Shahkulu revolt against this empire, many Shi’a joined forces with members of a syncretic Muslim tradition prominent in this empire’s homeland. This (*) non-Persian empire persecuted the remaining qizilbash in lands that it gained following its decisive victory at the Battle of Chaldiran. Mass murder committed by this empire drove the Alevis underground. Religious minority groups in this empire were governed under the millet system. For 10 points, name this empire whose devshirme system turned Christian minority children into Janissaries.
tossups.answer: Ottoman Empire [or Devlet-i ‘Alīye-i ‘Osmānīye] <WA, World History>

tossups.question: 13. In this novel, a cat destroys one character’s Polish pigskin briefcase and tears apart a report about the Bipartite Para-Models of Missile Flight. A character in this novel names his pet spider “Easy Rider” at the behest of his 6-year-old son Paul. A man in this novel, who is described as a “good atheist jew,” fails to persuade Ed to continue their homosexual relationship and leaves his job at the Datatronics company. In this novel, a drummer for the punk band (*) Liquid Sheep posts a dating advertisement for her friend to the personals section of the Bay Guardian. Father O’Hare leads a march against the Lungless Labs in this novel, which becomes a central point of conflict between the main character of this novel and his lover, Liz Dorati. This novel focuses on the virulent anti-peacenik, John Brown, and is composed of 590 Onegin stanzas. For 10 points, name this verse novel by Vikram Seth.
tossups.answer: The Golden Gate <SB, LongFic>

tossups.question: Note to players: ethnicity and polity required. Aspiring mathematical students from this group were denied entry to their country’s mathematical institutes through deceptively simple “coffin problems.” In his memoir Love and Math, a Berkeley mathematician described his experience of systemic discrimination as a member of this group. This specific group was the impetus for passing the Jackson–Vanik amendment. The movement Nativ specifically sought to contact these people. The most famous subgroup of the (*) refuseniks was this ethnic group, whose namesake movement in the United States advocated that they pursue aliyah. The “Secret Letter” alleged that doctors of this group planned to poison Joseph Stalin. For 10 points, name this ethnic group that, under the previous government, was confined to the Pale of Settlement by Catherine the Great.
tossups.answer: Soviet Jews [or the Soviet Jewry Movement; accept clear equivalents like Jews from the Soviet Union; accept Union of Soviet Socialist Republics or USSR or Soyuz Sovetskikh Sotsialisticheskikh Respublik or CCCP in place of the Soviet Union; accept Ashkenazi Jews or Ashkenazim in place of “Jews”; accept refuseniks before it is read; prompt on Russian Jews; prompt on Jews in the Eastern Bloc or Jews in the Warsaw Pact] <AA, Continental History>

tossups.question: 15. Wilfred Thesiger described the practice in this region of building large stone cairns called waidellas. Archaeological evidence suggests that the port of Zeila was used to export the products of salt mines in this region’s Danakil desert. Though not in Tanzania, this region is home to the oldest known deposits of Olduwan style tools. In this region, Zeremsaray Alemseged discovered the oldest known fossil of a hominid child and gave it the name Selam. Many fossils have been discovered in this region by the Middle Awash project. This region lends its name to a (*) species of hominid discovered by Donald Johanson and named after a Beatles song; that fossil, Lucy, is from this region’s namesake Australopithecus species. For 10 points, name this roughly triangular area of low land in northern Ethiopia and Eritrea.
tossups.answer: Afar Depression [or Afar Triangle; accept Australopithecus afarensis; prompt on Ethiopia or East Africa] <WA, Archaeology>

tossups.question: 16. Two followers of a man actually named Lucifer of Cagliari listed numerous shortcomings of a holder of this title in the Libellus Precum. A holder of this title named Hormisdas helped end a dispute that broke out after the Henotikon failed to broker agreement. A popular legend claims that holders of this title had to sit on a chair with a hole in it and have their genitals felt to ensure they were male. A man with this title (*) negotiated with Genseric to preserve a city’s ancient buildings from a sack, and led an embassy which convinced the loser at Catalaunian fields to turn home. Lorenzo Valla debunked a forgery that claimed Constantine I transferred authority of the Western empire to a holder of this title. For 10 points, name this title held by the successor to Saint Peter, the first Bishop of Rome.
tossups.answer: popes [or pappas or papa; accept antipope or antipapas] <WA, Ancient History>

tossups.question: 17. While a woman and a fish seller squabble in a play by this author, the title character is able to escape through an open window and successfully evade one of the sinister “daughters of Eve.” After being told that people like to be remembered by what they leave behind, a character in a play by this author asks “who does not seek to be remembered? Memory is the master of death.” This author created a character who tells the tale of a bird that flies around the world to inform people of their impending (*) death, but each time receives the response “Not I.” Olunde mistakenly believes that a change in the sound of the drums means that his father has died in a play by this author. Simon Pilkings looks to put a stop to the ritual suicide of Elesin Oba in that play by this author. For 10 points, name this Nigerian playwright of Death and the King’s Horseman.
tossups.answer: Wole Soyinka <SB, Drama>

tossups.question: 18. Terrorists of this ethnicity were responsible for the 1968 bombing of a Bank of Tokyo Trust office at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Prisoners of this ethnicity started a 1987 riot in Atlanta when told they could be repatriated. The terrorist groups Omega 7 and Alpha 66 were primarily composed of people of this ethnicity. Several children of this ethnicity were brought to the United States in Operation Peter Pan, many of whom migrated to Union City, New Jersey. A mass movement of these people into the US was triggered by Hector (*) Sanyustiz driving a bus through the walls of an embassy. Janet Reno had a child of this ethnicity returned to his home country in a high-profile custody case in 2000. The Mariel Boatlift affected these people, who include Elian Gonzalez. For 10 points, name this ethnic group whose members include Rafael Cruz, many of whom came to Florida after Castro came to power.
tossups.answer: Cuban-Americans [prompt on Latin-Americans or Hispanics or Latinos or Latinx or similar answers] <EM, US History>

tossups.question: 19. In a novel from this country, a lengthy lawsuit about a man’s death from poisoning is marred by the revelation that a boy had premarital sex with the daughter of a nyai. That novel’s author recounted fourteen years of political imprisonment in The Mute’s Soliloquy. D. H. Lawrence’s preface to a novel set in this modern day country identifies a “passionate, honourable hate” like that of Swift or Gogol in an idyllic scene about Saïdjah [sah-EED-yah] and Adinda. This country is the setting of a coming-of-age novel about the boy Minke titled (*) This Earth of Mankind and the other novels in the Buru Quartet. A colonial system of agriculture used in this country, the “Cultivation System,” is exploited by the merchant Drystubble in a satire of the coffee industry here by Edward Dekker. For 10 points, the novel Max Havelaar by Multatuli depicts Dutch colonialism in what Asian country?
tossups.answer: (Republic of) Indonesia (the Buru Quartet is by Pramoedya Ananta Toer) <WA, LongFic>

tossups.question: 20. This character reflects religious women key to Nile fertility rites, according to Elizabeth Drew’s book on “the design of the poetry” of her creator. Grover Smith’s article on this character introduced a myth that she was based on a woman from Ecbatana in Aldous Huxley’s Crome Yellow. She may refer to a da Vinci work by noting “Here is Belladonna, the Lady of the Rocks” and speaks of a “one-eyed (*) merchant” who is later represented as Smyrna native Mr. Eugenides. This character notes “Those are pearls that were his eyes. Look!” about a figure who is later incarnated as the Phoenician Phlebas, the Drowned Sailor. This character is known as the “wisest woman in Europe” and has a “mean pack of cards.” For 10 points, name this “famous clairvoyant” from T. S. Eliot’s “The Waste Land.”
tossups.answer: Madame Sosostris [prompt on Madame] <WA, Poetry>

tossups.question: 21. A letter by this politician to activist Arthur Young was published alongside a piece opposing an agricultural minimum wage titled Thoughts and Details on Scarcity. The cartoon Cincinnatus in Retirement lampoons this politician’s support for Catholic Emancipation. This politician wrote that “A state without the means of some change is without the means of its conservation” in a work that notes “the age of chivalry is gone.” This politician criticized colleagues’ punitive fiscal measures in the (*) Speech on American Taxation, which was later followed by his Speech on Conciliation with America. This fierce opponent of Warren Hastings criticized Richard Price’s abstract principles of the “rights of man” in a piece of invective against Jacobin thuggery. For 10 points, name this author of Reflections on the Revolution in France.
tossups.answer: Edmund Burke <WA, Phil/SS>

tossups.question: 22. This phenomenon is [emphasize] contrasted with one that is “considered a promotion” when experienced by Hans Castorp in a book that illustrates attitudes about this phenomenon with a line from W. H. Auden’s “Miss Gee” about how this is a “funny thing.” A book exploring this phenomenon’s “mythology” argues it was considered appropriate for “life’s losers,” but inappropriate for melancholic, romantic characters. This phenomenon “existed in silence” until Herodotus’s discussion of Queen Atossa, according to a Pulitzer-winning book by (*) Siddhartha Mukherjee. Life with this condition is the subject of When Breath Becomes Air by Paul Kalanithi. An experience with this condition led to a 1978 book attacking victim-blaming mentalities which notes how this condition was linked to evil, unlike tuberculosis. For 10 points, Susan Sontag’s Illness as Metaphor is based on her experience with what condition?
tossups.answer: cancer [accept specific types such as leukemia or breast cancer; accept “Cancer’s a funny thing”; prompt on illness or sickness or maladies] <WA, Miscellaneous Lit>

tossups.question: 23. The first English translation of one of this author’s books came about after Blanche Knopf assumed that that book by this author contained a highbrow sex manual. For their explicit depictions of sexuality, two books by this author became the last to be placed on the Index of Forbidden Books. The thesis of this author’s anti-Freud chapter, “The Psychoanalytic Point of View,” was borrowed by such authors as Kate Millett. The scope of (*) Camille Paglia’s Sexual Personae was directly inspired by the scope taken by this author, whom Paglia credits as a major influence because she was also “raised Catholic,” as illustrated by Memoirs of a Dutiful Daughter. A ménage à trois with this author’s husband and Olga Kosakiewicz was depicted in She Came to Stay. For 10 points, name this author who wrote about the title group of French intellectuals in The Mandarins, and who also wrote The Second Sex.
tossups.answer: Simone de Beauvoir <WA, Literary Legacy>

tossups.question: 24. Much slaughter in the aftermath of this conflict was perpetrated by a red-haired, wild-eyed man with the surname Zombi. Intervention in this conflict was facilitated by the Treaty of Amiens, which lifted a British blockade. Leaders in this conflict announced their political goals at Camp Turel. The U.S. sent naval backing to the victorious side of a portion of this broader conflict called the War of Knives. Controlling this conflict was the responsibility of Léger-Félicité Sonthonax [lay-ZHAY fay-lee-see-TAY son-toh-NOX], an appointee of the (*) Committee of Public Safety. A leader in this conflict later proclaimed himself Emperor Henry I. Yellow fever killed most of the troops sent with Charles Leclerc to suppress the rebels in this conflict, which took place in the colony of Saint-Domingue [san doh-MANG]. For 10 points, name this successful slave revolt in which Jean-Jacques Dessalines expelled the French from a Caribbean island.
tossups.answer: Haitian Revolution [accept any answers referring to a revolt or revolution in Haiti] <WA, World History>
